tiers.title: Essential
tiers.subtitle: Start Here
tiers.description: The must-haves for any home bar. These six tools will let you make 90% of classic cocktails.

tools.name: Jigger
tools.subtitle: Japanese Style, 1oz/2oz
tools.description: A jigger ensures consistent pours every time. The Japanese style has a sleek profile and internal measurement lines for precise measurements.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Eyeballing measurements leads to inconsistent drinks. A jigger is the difference between a balanced cocktail and a boozy mess. Even professional bartenders use jiggers for precision.
whatToLookFor: Sturdy construction - thin metal dents easily
Japanese style for precision, American style for speed

tools.name: Boston Shaker
tools.subtitle: 18oz + 28oz Tins
tools.description: The Boston shaker is the industry standard. Two pieces - a smaller tin that fits into a larger one - with no built-in strainer, giving you maximum volume for shaking.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: The Boston shaker chills drinks faster than cobbler shakers and is easier to clean. It's what you'll see in every professional bar because it just works better.
whatToLookFor: 18oz and 28oz tin combo (or tin + tempered mixing glass)
Weighted bottom for stability on the bar

tools.name: Bar Spoon
tools.subtitle: Twisted Handle, 12 inch
tools.description: A bar spoon's twisted handle lets you stir drinks smoothly without introducing too much air. The long length reaches the bottom of tall mixing glasses.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Stirring with a regular spoon introduces too much dilution and aeration. A bar spoon creates the silky texture that spirit-forward cocktails like Martinis and Manhattans demand.
whatToLookFor: Weighted end or teardrop for balance

tools.name: Hawthorne Strainer
tools.subtitle: Spring-loaded, Fits Shaker Tin
tools.description: The Hawthorne strainer has a coiled spring that fits inside your shaker tin, catching ice and large particles while letting the liquid through.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Keeps ice and large particles out of your drink when pouring from a shaker. The spring creates a tight seal against the tin for clean pours every time.
whatToLookFor: Tight spring coil that holds its shape
Fits your specific shaker tin size

tools.name: Muddler
tools.subtitle: Wooden or Stainless Steel
tools.description: A muddler releases oils from herbs and juice from fruit. Essential for drinks like Mojitos, Old Fashioneds, and Smashes.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Properly muddled ingredients release their essential oils and flavors without becoming bitter. A good muddler gives you control over how much extraction you get.
whatToLookFor: Flat bottom (not toothed) - toothed muddlers shred herbs
Long enough to reach bottom of a mixing glass

tools.name: Citrus Juicer
tools.subtitle: Handheld Press Style
tools.description: Fresh citrus is non-negotiable for quality cocktails. A handheld press juicer extracts maximum juice with minimal effort.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Bottled juice tastes flat and oxidized. Fresh-squeezed citrus is the single biggest upgrade you can make to your cocktails. A press juicer makes it quick and easy.
whatToLookFor: Handles lemons AND limes (some are sized for one or the other)
Sturdy hinge that won't bend under pressure

tiers.title: Level Up
tiers.subtitle: Expand Your Arsenal
tiers.description: Ready to go beyond the basics? These tools unlock new techniques and refine your craft.

tools.name: Mixing Glass
tools.subtitle: Weighted Base, 500-700ml
tools.description: A dedicated mixing glass for stirred cocktails. The thick glass walls stay cold longer and the weighted base keeps it stable while stirring.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: While you can stir in your shaker tin, a proper mixing glass looks better and performs better. The visual of stirring a Manhattan in crystal clear glass is part of the experience.

tools.name: Fine Mesh Strainer
tools.subtitle: For Double-Straining
tools.description: A fine mesh strainer catches the small ice shards and pulp that slip through a Hawthorne strainer, giving you a perfectly clear drink.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Double-straining removes tiny ice chips that dilute your drink and citrus pulp that clouds it. Essential for elegant cocktails served up.
whatToLookFor: Fine mesh that catches small particles
Handle long enough to hold comfortably

tools.name: Channel Knife
tools.subtitle: For Citrus Twists
tools.description: A channel knife cuts thin strips of citrus peel for elegant twists and garnishes. Creates those long spiraling peels you see in craft cocktail bars.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: A channel knife creates uniform, professional-looking twists that a regular peeler can't match. The thin strips express oils without adding bitterness from the pith.

tools.name: Julep Strainer
tools.subtitle: For Stirred Drinks
tools.description: The julep strainer is designed for stirred drinks in a mixing glass. Its perforated bowl shape fits perfectly against the ice.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: While you can use a Hawthorne strainer for everything, a julep strainer gives you more control with stirred drinks and looks more elegant when making cocktails at the bar.
whatToLookFor: Perforations sized to catch ice but not slow the pour
Curved shape that fits mixing glasses

tools.name: Pour Spouts
tools.subtitle: Speed Pourers
tools.description: Pour spouts replace bottle caps for faster, more controlled pours. They let air in as liquid comes out for a smooth, consistent flow.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Speed pourers give you consistent flow rates, making free-pouring more accurate. They also make it easier to pour multiple ingredients quickly.
whatToLookFor: Metal spouts over plastic for durability
Tapered design for standard bottle necks
Dust caps for bottles you use less often

tools.name: Ice Cube Trays
tools.subtitle: Large Format, 2 inch Cubes
tools.description: Large ice cubes melt slower, keeping your drink cold longer without diluting it as quickly. Essential for spirit-forward drinks served on the rocks.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Big ice isn't just for looks - the lower surface-to-volume ratio means slower dilution. An Old Fashioned stays strong longer with a 2-inch cube than with regular ice.

tiers.title: Pro Status
tiers.subtitle: Advanced Gear
tiers.description: For the serious home bartender. These specialized tools unlock professional techniques and show you mean business.

tools.name: Japanese Jigger Set
tools.subtitle: Multiple Sizes
tools.description: A set of Japanese-style jiggers in multiple sizes gives you the precision to measure any amount without math or guesswork.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Having dedicated jiggers for common measurements (0.5oz, 0.75oz, 1oz, 1.5oz, 2oz) means faster, more accurate pours. No more filling a jigger halfway.

tools.name: Lewis Bag & Mallet
tools.subtitle: For Crushed Ice
tools.description: The canvas Lewis bag absorbs water while you crush ice with a wooden mallet, creating dry, fluffy crushed ice for Juleps and Swizzles.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Blender-crushed ice is wet and clumpy. A Lewis bag creates the dry, snow-like ice that proper Mint Juleps and Tiki drinks demand.
whatToLookFor: Wooden mallet that won't damage the bag
Bag size that holds enough ice for several drinks

tools.name: Smoking Gun
tools.subtitle: For Smoked Cocktails
tools.description: A handheld smoker infuses drinks with wood smoke flavor. Fill a glass with smoke, trap it, then pour in your cocktail for dramatic presentation.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Smoke adds complexity and theater to cocktails. A Smoked Old Fashioned isn't just delicious - it's an experience your guests will remember.

tools.name: Atomizer
tools.subtitle: For Absinthe Rinses and Spritzes
tools.description: An atomizer sprays a fine mist of spirits or bitters on top of drinks or inside glasses for aromatic impact without adding volume.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: A Sazerac needs an absinthe rinse - an atomizer gives you that wash of flavor without drowning the drink. Also perfect for aromatic bitters on top of cocktails.
whatToLookFor: Glass bottle that won't react with spirits

tools.name: Fine Scale
tools.subtitle: 0.1g Precision for Bitters
tools.description: A precision scale measures ingredients by weight instead of volume. Essential for recipes that call for exact amounts of bitters or tinctures.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Weight is more accurate than volume for small amounts. When a recipe calls for 2 dashes of bitters, a scale tells you exactly what that means in grams.
whatToLookFor: Tare function for zeroing with a glass

tools.name: Sous Vide
tools.subtitle: For Rapid Infusions
tools.description: A sous vide circulator rapidly infuses spirits with flavors that would take weeks using traditional methods. Make custom bitters, infused syrups, and flavored spirits.
tools.whyYouNeedIt: Traditional infusions take days or weeks. Sous vide infuses flavors in hours while preserving delicate notes that heat would destroy.
whatToLookFor: Works with Mason jars or vacuum bags
